FacilityName: Omaha Public Power Nebraska City Power Station

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The following is a brief description of OPPDs Prevention Program which
includes a well developed a hazard assessment and review program,
managements systems, robust safety systems, safe operating
procedures, maintenance procedures, emergency response planning,
incident investigation, and compliance auditing.
Hazard Assessment ? OPPD has developed worst-case release
scenarios and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia process.
The worst case and alternative release analysis involves an off-site
consequence analysis of releases for ammonia.
To conduct this hazard assessment, OPPD has review flow charts, P&IDs
to illustrate the covered process. This review included an evaluation of
process safety equipment, mechanical integrity evaluation adequacy, and
equipment adequacy as defined by compliance with engineering/industry
standards and codes.
Management Systems - OPPD has in place management systems to
assist in prevention of a release; the management system includes the
following:
?Documentation of policies/procedures
?Definition of responsibilities
?Specification of approvals or authorizations
?Description of required training and experience
?Measures of protection
?System of documentation?System of verification
Safety System Information ?OPPD has summarized process safety
information to provide information to prevent an accidental release. Safety
system information includes; hazard communication, lock-out/tag-out,
confined space, and respiratory protection program elements with respect
to the potential hazards associated with ammonia.
Hazard Review ? OPPD has performed a Hazard Review of the hazards
associated with ammonia at the facility. The Hazard Review was
developed and included the following to elements to prevent an accidental
release of ammonia:
?Identified the hazards associated with the SCR process and the use of
ammonia.
?Identified opportunities for equipment malfunction or human errors that
could cause an accidental release.
?Outlined the safeguards used or needed to control the hazards or
prevent equipment malfunction or human error.
?Included those steps used or needed to detect or monitor releases.
?Provided worker and area exposure monitoring plans for ammonia, and
will implement this plan.
Operating Procedures ? OPPD has developed written operating
procedures for the safe storage and handling of ammonia at the NC
facility. The procedures specify steps for each operating phase of the
process and operating limits (e.g., pressure in the tanks). OPPD has
outlined appropriate safety and health considerations and incorporated
them into the safe operating procedures.
OPPD will provide up-to-date process flow diagrams that detail process
control mechanisms (i.e., valves, pressure regulators, gauges, vent
stacks, heating and pressure differential mechanisms).
Training OPPD has a training program related to operation, inspection,
and maintenance of the SCR ammonia system to ensure safe operation.
Maintenance ? OPPD has reviewed procedures for maintaining the
integrity of the process equipment. OPPD has identified inspections and
maintenance procedures needed to comply with the standard. The
maintenance program is in accordance with good engineering practice
and in accordance with manufacturer?s recommendations.
Emergency Response Planning ?OPPD has reviewed Emergency
Response Plans for the facility and ensures compliance with the Risk
Management standard.
Incident Investigation ? OPPD has review incident investigation protocols
to assure that all the elements of the RMP regulations are included.
Compliance Audits ? OPPD states the RMP will be certified and evaluated
for compliance with the provisions of the RMP rule every three (3) years.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Omaha Public Power District (OPPD) and OPPD Nebraska City Power Station management and on-site work force are firmly committed to safety. Each level of management is directly responsible for the implementation of the OPPD accident prevention program and responsible for the safety performance of their employees. An active safety management team comprised of members from all departments and all levels of management participates in process hazard analysis and safety implementation review. OPPD has a comprehensive training program that includes training of on-site hazardous waste operations and emergency response (HAZWOPER) personnel to the 29 CFR 1910.120 technician level. In addition, OPPD conducts ammonia general awareness training and training for contractors as to the hazards of ammonia and their responsibilities in emergency response.

OPPD?s Nebraska City site is a coal fired power plant. This site is located in a rural, sparsely populated section of Otoe County. The plant uses one listed toxic chemical, anhydrous ammonia, above threshold quantities. Anhydrous ammonia is stored and used in the operation of the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system. Upon analysis of the Worst case scenarios, anhydrous ammonia was potentially released in quantities sufficient to reach off-site receptors via air dispersion routes. 

The worst case scenario included the release of chemical from the ammonia storage which is a high volume storage vessel. Ammonia's worst-case release volume was 53,300 pounds that being the entire quantity of the ammonia storage tank. Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, anhydrous ammonia does potentially reach offsite residences at a distance of 4.5 miles that being the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia?s worst case scenario radii, and 1.5 miles for the alternate case scenario.

The anhydrous ammonia process is a new process associated with the construction of a new power plant (NC2) and consequently does not have an accid

ental release history relative to offsite impacts as provided in the risk management program rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)). Additional measures were necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental release and these measures included coordination with the potential off-site emergency responders and near-by municipalities. Active mitigation includes an emergency shut off system and excess flow valves. In the event of fire, explosion, or release of the regulated substance, anhydrous ammonia: entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency responders. Therefore, public emergency responders that are not HAZWOPER trained as technicians will not enter the area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP. These issues will be discussed annually during the emergency response training.

The alternate case scenario involves the release of anhydrous during tanker truck unloading as a consequence of 3 inch inner bore diameter pipe break or release from a pressure relief valve associated with this piping. The anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the receiving loop of the system which is maintained at a pressure less than or equal to 300 psi. The calculations for the anhydrous ammonia alternate scenario portray the release of anhydrous ammonia assuming a release rate of 1800 pounds per minute. Response time for the on-site HAZWOPER personnel given donning requirements for personal protective equipment and assemblage of response teams is estimated to be 10 minutes. Even with these estimates, the alternate case toxic endpoint radii does reach public receptors and residences. These assumptions are very conservative given the realization that the overpressure would be shutdown as soon as a tanker truck spill was occurring.  However, assuming multiple failures -- including failure of the anhydrous ammonia overpressure shutdown system; this alternate scenario has been developed.

Alarm systems and emergency response are dir

ected as initial evacuation occurs. Re-entry with personal protective equipment including respiratory protection and monitoring instrumentation is required if the ambient atmosphere ammonia levels exceed 25 parts per million. Emergency response is coordinated with the Nebraska City Fire Department, Otoe County Emergency Planning Committee, and the Fremont County Emergency Planning Committee. A written Emergency Response Plan is provided to these emergency response organizations. Both emergency response and emergency medical procedures are documented and are emphasized during emergency response training on-site. Spill response kits are available onsite to be used by the on-site HAZWOPER technician trained personnel to handle spills that exceed those associated with normal operations and maintenance activities. OPPD is continually evaluating the hazards of operation and proceeding to fully integrate OSHA (for the contractor work force), EPA, and State of Nebraska requirements.  Additionally, OPPD plans to install a deluge water suppression system to further improve mitigation capability. 

The anhydrous ammonia use constitutes a Program Level 3 and OPPD has a Program Level 3 Prevention Program for anhydrous ammonia.
